en: Map History of the 1st Armored Division
Route map of North Africa (Italy on other side)
Canvas for Map History of the 1st Armored Division

body.value: Map title and blank label, intended to be folded and mailed.
Legend and insignia of the 1st Armored Division. "Africa Nov '42 - May '43"

1. On 8 November 1942, armored columns landed on the Algerian coast east and west of Oran.  A seaborne assault on the city resulted in disaster to the 3rd Battalion of the 6th Armored Infantry, but the tank columns isolated the city in two days.  Oran surrendered 10 November after 1st Armored light tanks entered the city.

#2 The 1st Battalion of the 1st Armored Regiment and the 2nd Battalion of the 13th Armored Regiment led the Division into the Tunisian campaign.  Attached to a British force, the tanks attacked on 25 November 1942 through Chouigui, Tebourba and Djedeida.  At Djedeida the light tanks of the 1st A.R. surprised 54 Stukas on an airport and left 48 of the planes burning.  Also early into action in November were "B" and "C" Companies of the 701st Tank Destroyers at Medjez el Bab, Gafsa, and Kasserine Pass

#3 CC "B" arrived at the Tunisian front on 1 December 1942 and took over a sector straddling the Medjez-Tebourba road.  After several days of tank duels, the Germans launched a full-scale land and air attack down the road.  CC "B" was forced back.  Rain mired down their vehicles and most men walked out.  "C" Battery of the 27th Armored Field Artillery earned a Presidential citation for a heroic stand against the enemy armor.

#4 The remainder of the 1st Armored arrived in Tunisia in late January.  They raided Station de Sened twice before CC "A" took over a sector opposite Faid Pass the last of the month.  On 14 February the Germans threw three panzer divisions against the light CC "A" force.  The Kraut armor chewed up two battalions of medium tanks, punched through the Sidi bou Zid to Kern's Crossroads.  Two wired-in infantry battalions on Djebel Ksaira and Djebel Lessouda were surrounded by the Germans.

#5 The Division stemmed the Germans at Sbeitla until 17 February, when they withdrew through Kasserine Pass.  The 68th Armored Field Artillery earned a Presidential Citation for their role in blocking and slowing the German spearhead.  In Kasserine on 20 February the Germans attacked again, were mauled when they reached the valley floor and forced back.  Three days later the pass was recaptured and the Division assembled at El Ma el Abiod.  During the next two weeks the Germans withdrew to their starting point at Faid Pass.

#6 On the 26th of February, the Division went into Corps Reserve where it remained until 11th March, refitting and reorganizing.  The German drive had been smashed, but at heavy cost.  During the period the 81st Cavalry Reconnaissance Squadron maintained contact with the retreating enemy until he reestablished his original line, Faid-Rebaou.  On 12th March, the Division once more rolled south on the offensive.

#7 In March the Division attacked through Station de Sened toward Maknassy.  On 22 March the tanks and infantry rolled through Maknassy toward Djebel Dribica and Djebel Naemia.  The Germans reinforced their mountain positions and the fight turned into a deadlock.  To the south the Germans were slowly forced back through El Guettar.  On 7 April 1st Armored reconnaisance vehicles broke through to contact the northbound British Eight Army.  To days later the Division was headed north for their part in the knock-out blow of the campaign.

#8 The "Mousetrap" was a saucer-like valley held on the south by the Allies and on the north by the Germans. It led to the Tunis-Bizerte plain.  The 6th Infantry painstakingly cleaned out the hills on the right of the valley.  The break came on 3 May, and the tanks and halftracks of the 1st Armored poured through toward Mateur.  The disorganized Germans fell back, blowing bridges where they could be doing little to slow the attack.

#9 The Germans momentarily halted the assault near Ferryville, but on 7 May the town was captured and the tankers found themselves 10 miles from the Tunis-Bizerte road.  The tanks raced cross-country, cut the important highway by fire and trapped thousands of Germans between the 1st Armored and the British 1st Army, which had reached Tunis.  The next morning the tanks swung north toward Bizerte and the German defenses cracked wide open. At 1055 hours on 8 May 1943 two German generals reported to the division CP to surrender their 40,000 Nazi troops to the commander of the 1st Armored. The African was was finished.
